postHtml:
David Glasser
4 hrs ·

So, to be clear, the story of the Nevada caucuses is that the candidate who more Nevadans voted for is getting more delegates, right?

LikeShow more reactions
CommentShare
222
Comments
View 4 more comments
Richard Tibbetts It bothers me that the media is mostly not using this opportunity to educate people about the role and structure of political parties. The nominee is supposed to be chosen by the party, but it is neither the reality nor the ideal that they be chosen in a particular mechanistic way, certainly not by simple popular vote.
Like · Reply · 3 hrs
Micah Haley replied · 5 Replies · 10 mins
Anna Barr Folinsky Don't be silly Dave. We all know Nevada isn't real.
Like · Reply · 2 hrs
Micah Haley replied · 3 Replies · 2 hrs
Jeffrey Wescott We will never know, because the recount was denied.

Watch the video.
Like · Reply · 1 · 2 hrs
Jeffrey Wescott Also, LMK if you want to join Stephan and Matthew's bet against Jeremy and myself.

Basically, they've given us 10-1 odds that HRC will beat Trump. I've got $105 riding on a Trump victory, which would win me the saddest $1050 I've ever had. Might be enough for my ticket to Germany, though.
Like · Reply · 1 · 2 hrs
Matthew Lewis replied · 5 Replies · 40 mins

postHtml:
Norian Caporale-Berkowitz
4 hrs ·

“How much do you know about Shakespeare,” I once asked a friend who has committed much of her life to studying the Bard. She replied, “Not as much as he knows about me.” Remember this the next time someone tells you literature is useless.

The author Arnold Weinstein is my mentor and prof from Brown, and his twin brother was my neighbor growing up - funny coincidence!

Don’t Turn Away From the Art of Life
Our data-driven culture bears much of the blame for the decline of the humanities in higher education.
nytimes.com|By Arnold Weinstein
LikeShow more reactions
CommentShare

postHtml:
Ben Woosley
24 mins ·

The Nevada Democratic convention was bonkers. Anyone who has faith in our democratic process should watch these videos. Basically, when those who control the system do not get their way according to the publicly-stated, generally-agreeable rules, they override the rules in their own favor to force their own position. Thus a result is presented as democratic in nature but is factually an autocratic decision produced by an autocratic process.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5sr...PXtJV0V0
https://amp.twimg.com/v/f6d570ac-07e0-434f-9d8e-8dc29129a400

h/t Tim League

See More
Internal Coup in the Democratic Party
I had to upload this. I was planning on starting my own channel in the future, with far more edited films and edited content but this just made my blood boil...
youtube.com

CommentShare
Comments

postHtml:
Qiaochu Yuan
4 hrs ·

FYI, there was someone pretending to be me on Facebook, but the account was reported and now appears to be gone. I'm impressed it happened so quickly but a little worried that it happened at all.

LikeShow more reactions
CommentShare
9110Sergei Shlomo Bernstein and 9 others
Comments
Eliezer Yudkowsky Are you sure they were pretending to be you, not pretending to be that duplicate Qiaochu Yuan you ran into a while back?
Like · Reply · 4 · 4 hrs
Qiaochu Yuan replied · 1 Reply
Harsh Pareek A personal attack or a clever spammer trying to copy profiles and sound legitimate? ie making posts like you or exactly copying your posts?
Like · Reply · 2 hrs
Jaclyn Wilson This literally just happened with my uncle's account; used a picture of his and sent me the friend request, and messaged me asking how I was doing. I and possibly other family members reported it, and it's already gone as well.
Like · Reply · 24 mins
text: FYI, there was someone pretending to be me on Facebook, but the account was reported and now appears to be gone. I'm impressed it happened so quickly but a little worried that it happened at all.
